Like many of Cameron's films, “Avatar: Fire and Ash” jumps from genre to genre and encompasses a wide tonal range, from rousing action to intimate romance and mourning. Franglen was tasked with creating a score worthy of the depth and breadth of Cameron's storytelling, which required him to call upon a wide range of styles and influences. It all began, however, with character.

 










“It has to start with the disconnect between Jake [Sam Worthington] and Neytiri [Zoe Saldaña],” Franglen said of the couple at the film's center, who are devastated by loss as the story begins. “Initially, when they talk, I'm using two lines that go apart from each other so that musically there's always a sense of distance between them. So you've got some very austere themes that have a very delicate color.”

By contrast, when Franglen created music for the Wind Traders, a nomadic air-traveling clan who sail the skies, he was able to cut loose with swashbuckling themes in the tradition of 1930s and 1940s Hollywood adventure films. The fact that the Wind Traders are seen playing instruments on camera meant that not only did Franglen have to compose music for their performances, he needed to create the instruments they were playing.

“I had to design real instruments because they're performing, and in ‘Avatar' we can't make shit up,” Franglen said, referring to Cameron's mandate that everything in the film be rooted in reality. Franglen worked closely with production designers Dylan Cole and Ben Procter as well as costume designer Deborah L. Scott to create the culture of the Wind Traders and then build his instruments accordingly. 

“I saw them as Phoenician traders of old,” Franglen said. “They're much more sophisticated than other clans we've met in the past. I can't give them guitar, bass, and drums, but they have to be playing music. So I sketched out some instruments and decided to make drum heads from the same material as the sails. And I wanted the string instruments to feel like the rigging of the ship, because these are nomads. They should have instruments that reflect what they're doing.” Franglen gave his sketches to the art department to create 3D renderings, and then prop master Brad Elliott created the actual playable instruments on an enormous 3D printer. 

 










For the film's other new clan, the Ash people, Franglen took a different approach. “The Ash are chaos agents, and I wanted their music to have a visceral quality,” Franglen said. “10 years ago, I'd been in Inner Mongolia, and they have a string instrument called a morin khuur that can have a real ferocity, so I built a texture around that. But I didn't want to give the Ash a theme, I wanted to give them a feeling.”

To that end, Franglen utilized the tritone, a dissonant musical interval also known as “the devil's interval.” “It's never quite settled,” Franglen said. “You hear it when they first attack, and later, even if there are just hints of it, it became a motif that I could use.”

Aside from a vocal group from the Pacific Islands, all of the music in “Fire and Ash” was recorded in Los Angeles on the Fox lot, a fact in which Franglen takes justifiable pride. A total of 215 musicians comprised an ensemble that included a 100-piece orchestra, choirs, soloists, percussion, and custom synthesizer programming — all of which combine to yield a varied and powerful score that both invites and earns comparisons with those of epics past, like Maurice Jarre's work in “Lawrence of Arabia” and “Doctor Zhivago.” 

As in those films, the music of “Avatar: Fire and Ash” manages to sound huge without losing sight of the more delicate human moments at the story's center. “I wanted to give an organic sense that you're telling a story with the music,” Franglen said. “I wanted to create an emotional connection.” Eight years after he first began writing the score, Franglen still marvels at the scope of the project. “If you look at my history, I've been involved in some chunky things. But this one really is at a whole other level of complexity.”

 










“Avatar: Fire and Ash” opens in theaters on Friday, December 19.
